item.description:
When the American colonists gave up tea to protest British taxation, they turned to drinking chocolate instead. American Heritage Chocolate is dedicated to preserving the colonial tradition of making chocolate, and employees will be on hand at the Old South Meeting House to demonstrate seventeenth-century chocolate making.

*****From the Old South Meeting House website:

A Rich History: A Celebration of Chocolate at Our Annual Holiday Open House

With the rebellion against tea in the colonial era, our forefathers chose a more opulent and rich drink to symbolize freedom -- hot chocolate! Join the team from American Heritage Chocolate to ring in the holidays at the Old South Meeting House with a taste of handcrafted chocolates made with authentic seventeenth-century recipes. FREE and OPEN to the public.******

I called the Old South Meeting House, and the folks there informed me that they were giving a ten-minute talk about colonial beverages at 2 p.m. We'll learn how chocolate, coffee, and tea were served in the colonies. This is a good time to find me: I'll be at the 2 p.m. talk carrying a red backpack and wearing a red knit pullover. (I'll also try to remember my meetup sign.) I plan to be at the Old South Meeting House by 1:30 p.m. You might be able to find me in the Meeting House before 2 p.m., but it will probably be easier to look for me during the ten-minute talk.

After the talk, we can check out the chocolate-making demonstrations, which will continue after the talk until 3 p.m. I was also told that authentic seventeenth-century recipes and chocolate samples will be distributed to anyone who is willing to taste them. And that would be everyone, I imagine.

If you want more information, you can visit the Old South Meeting House website at http://www.osmh.org or the American Heritage Chocolate website at http://americanheritagechocolate.com.
item.name: Colonial Chocolate-Making Demonstrations at the Old South Meeting House
